ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to identify different rocks and minerals. We also learned about how landscapes form (geomorphology).
The ability to look at rocks and interpret geological information from them!
I learned the different mineral makeups of rocks, how those rocks formed, and the ways these rocks come together to form geographic features.
Basically how to identify and apply geology/the topics learned in the 110 to the real world!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this is a very fun and engaging course without being much work, even considering it is a half credit. Dave Evans is awesome, and the fall break field trip was very worthwhile and enjoyable. I didn't really know anyone in the class going in, but the collaborative work and the field trip made it one of the only classes at Yale where I actually made new friends and got to know the professor. It is way more intimate than the large Dynamic Earth lecture, and I also think you learn more than in the lecture because it is so hands-on. No major weaknesses if you think geology is cool.

Assignments could be more clear, especially the more complex new material. I felt that we were often taught the material as we were working on the question it pertained to, so it was sometimes hard to digest everything at once. Maybe I just felt this way because I am not great at science, but I felt like the assignments could have been better explained.
This course has awesome field trips and gets you acquainted with the hands-on side of geology, which is valuable

Its biggest strengths are the three field trips during the semester. You really get to see geology up close and with an amazing and informative professor that can explain everything you see.

I don't think there is any major weakness to this course, but there could definitely be more organization to how information is given and explained.
Strengths: the field trips! Weaknesses: I felt like the final project and some of the labs were a little unclear

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely. Lots of fun and I actually felt like I learned a lot about how to identify rocks and such, especially during the field trips.

I don't even like science and I would say that this was a good way to get a half credit. You show up for class and do your assignment during class. Ideally, you have no work to do outside of the allotted 3 hours per week. Also, the TA is super helpful and nice.

Yes! The class, besides teaching us topics concerning geology, connected these to real-world places. Also, the Prof. Evans and James are amazing since they are available to answer any questions  we may have on the project.
Absolutely, especially if you are looking to major in anything rock-related (EPS, architecture, environmental science, archeology, etc)
Yes! It takes the dynamic earth course to a deeper level for those who want to really understand the concepts!
Yes, if you're a prospective EPS major.
